name: NEIAL-001
statement: To avoid the slogan 'Everything is a language', treat 'language' as a typed construct defined by testable properties (syntax, parsing, linear decoding pressure, and descriptor-role).
notes: This keeps 'can be interpreted' separate from 'is a language system'.

name: NEIAL-002
statement: Use the repo predicates: HasSyntax, RequiresParsing, HasLinearDecodingPressure, StableOntologyReference (spelled IsOngologyDescriptor in the dataset), plus auxiliary checks like CanBeHeld and HasIdentity.
formalization: Predicates: Syntax(x), Parse(x), SerializeMeaning(x), OntDesc(x), Tangible(x)
notes: We preserve the dataset's field name even when misspelled to match the generated schema.

name: NEIAL-003
statement: Operational definition: an item x counts as a Language if it has syntax, requires parsing, serializes meaning, and functions as an ontology/descriptor system.
notes: This is a deliberately 'strong' definition: it matches formal languages and many natural language representations.

name: NEIAL-004
statement: There exists at least one clear witness that satisfies the operational definition: English.
evidence_from_rulebook: HasSyntax=True; RequiresParsing=True; HasLinearDecodingPressure=True; IsOngologyDescriptor=True; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=False; DistanceFromConcept=2; Category=Natural Language
notes: If any predicate is false in your current dataset for this witness, adjust the candidate record or relax the definition.

name: NEIAL-005
statement: There exists at least one clear witness that satisfies the operational definition: Python.
evidence_from_rulebook: HasSyntax=True; RequiresParsing=True; HasLinearDecodingPressure=True; IsOngologyDescriptor=True; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=False; DistanceFromConcept=2; Category=Formal Language
notes: If any predicate is false in your current dataset for this witness, adjust the candidate record or relax the definition.

name: NEIAL-006
statement: Therefore, 'language' can be formalized as a computable classification boundary over explicit predicates.
notes: This is the concession: language is formalizable (at least operationally).

name: NEIAL-007
statement: If Language(x) is defined by necessary conditions, then any x that fails at least one condition is not a language.
notes: This is the standard move: a definition implies exclusions.

name: NEIAL-008
statement: Counterexample: a chair can be interpreted as a sign (status, design, function), but it does not constitute a language system under the operational definition.
notes: This separates semiotic availability (can signify) from linguistic structure (has syntax/parsing/serialized meaning).

name: NEIAL-009
statement: Non-language example: A Thunderstorm can be meaningful, but meaning here is not generated by an explicit syntax+parsing+serialization descriptor system.
evidence_from_rulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=True; HasLinearDecodingPressure=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=False; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Physical event
notes: These are strong candidates for 'sign vehicles' rather than 'languages'.

name: NEIAL-010
statement: Non-language example: A Coffee Mug can be meaningful, but meaning here is not generated by an explicit syntax+parsing+serialization descriptor system.
evidence_from_rulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=False; HasLinearDecodingPressure=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=False; CanBeHeld=True; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Physical Object
notes: These are strong candidates for 'sign vehicles' rather than 'languages'.

name: NEIAL-011
statement: Non-language example: The Mona Lisa can be meaningful, but meaning here is not generated by an explicit syntax+parsing+serialization descriptor system.
evidence_from_rulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=False; HasLinearDecodingPressure=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=True; CanBeHeld=True; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Physical Object
notes: These are strong candidates for 'sign vehicles' rather than 'languages'.

name: NEIAL-012
statement: Fuzzy case: A Running App often contains embedded languages (code, UI grammars), but as an executing/interactive process it behaves like a dynamic system rather than a static serialized language artifact.
formalization: Borderline(A Running App): may contain ∃y Language(y) but ¬Language(A Running App) under static-serialization criteria
notes: This is where traditional semiotics' 'anything is a sign' doesn’t neatly distinguish: (1) language-as-system vs (2) meaning-making interactive processes.

name: NEIAL-013
statement: Fuzzy case: Running Calculator App often contains embedded languages (code, UI grammars), but as an executing/interactive process it behaves like a dynamic system rather than a static serialized language artifact.
formalization: Borderline(Running Calculator App): may contain ∃y Language(y) but ¬Language(Running Calculator App) under static-serialization criteria
evidence_from_rulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=True; HasLinearDecodingPressure=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=False; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Running Software
notes: This is where traditional semiotics' 'anything is a sign' doesn’t neatly distinguish: (1) language-as-system vs (2) meaning-making interactive processes.

name: NEIAL-014
statement: Fuzzy case: A Game of Fortnite often contains embedded languages (code, UI grammars), but as an executing/interactive process it behaves like a dynamic system rather than a static serialized language artifact.
formalization: Borderline(A Game of Fortnite): may contain ∃y Language(y) but ¬Language(A Game of Fortnite) under static-serialization criteria
evidence_from_rulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=True; HasLinearDecodingPressure=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=False; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Running Software
notes: This is where traditional semiotics' 'anything is a sign' doesn’t neatly distinguish: (1) language-as-system vs (2) meaning-making interactive processes.

name: NEIAL-015
statement: Refinement: distinguish LanguageSystem (syntax/parsing/serialization descriptor) from SemioticProcess (interactive/dynamic meaning production) and from SignVehicle (object/phenomenon used as a sign).
notes: This gives you a place to put running apps and games without forcing 'language' to swallow everything.

name: NEIAL-016
statement: Given a formalizable definition of language, not everything is a language; some things are better treated as sign vehicles or semiotic processes, with running applications as a key fuzzy region that benefits from explicit modeling.
notes: This is the repo's thesis in one line.
